title: 18-of-the-most-exciting-and-affordable-scotch-whiskies-around-today
story: It sounds simple ndash as easy as making a cake ndash and, in essence, it is, but the finished product, a beautul glass of fine whisky, is a beguiling, mysterious, puzzling, wonderful creation.Earlier this year, I wrote an article on the opening of the new Macallan distillery on Speyside, and as part of it I needed to describe exactly what whisky meant to me. This is what I said:ldquoItrsquos friendship and memory, wonderful moments and the emotions that go with them ndash the perfect partner to unforgettable events in all our lives.ldquoIt is the heady night my first daughter was born, when I arrived home from hospital and poured an Old Fettercairn to make a joyful, tearful toast to my we and tiny new baby.ldquoOr the bright May evening outside the Kingrsquos House in Glen Coe after my friend and I had climbed Agagrsquos Groove on the Buachaille Etive Mor. We shared a hip flask of Springbank as we stared up at the mountain, and it was the best Irsquod ever tasted.ldquoIt is the evenings around my kitchen table with my pal from across the road, music playing a little bit too loud into the wee small hours as the whisky and stories and laughter flow.ldquoThese moments, these images of times to treasure, that ability to create wonderful memories. That is, at the absolute basic, the essence of whisky.People often say that something is greater than the sum of its parts ndash well, that phrase could have been coined especially for Scotlandrsquos national drink.Since I first fell in love with whisky in , Irsquove been lucky enough to try some unforgettable drams ... including one or two whose price tag ran into five figures.But over the years itrsquos become clear to me that you donrsquot have to pay thousands ndash or even hundreds ndash to get your hands on something really special.If you know what yoursquore looking for you can find a spectacular dram on a supermarket shelf or in your local whisky shop, and you certainly wonrsquot need to spend as much as you think.Over the following four pages, Irsquove listed a few of my favourites ndash some of the most interesting and exciting whiskies around today. And nearly all of them cost less than pound.If you like what you read, go out and buy a bottle ndash I promise you that you wonrsquot be disappointed.Good luck!Ardnamurchan  ADABV : .%Price: poundLetrsquos start at the very beginning hellip with a dram so young wersquore not even allowed to call it whisky.Itrsquos generally accepted that the older whisky is, the better it gets, but Ardnamurchan  AD is definitely the exception that proves the rule. It boasts a depth of flavour that belies its youth ndash a heady mix of sweetness and citric sharpness, but with the richness of dried fruits and a satisfying biscuity creaminess. Far off there are hints of pepper and the odd waft of smoke. Yum!The  AD continues parent company Adelphirsquos pioneering use of blockchain to give unique levels of provenance to every bottle. By scanning the unique QR code on the back label, consumers can trace every ingredient and every stage of the ldquomanufacturing process, from field to bottle.And,yoursquore still not convinced, just look at the bottle. Simple and sleek, it won  Scottish Design Awards for packaging.So with just , bottles of this beauty ever made, itrsquos definitely worth a quick dash to grab one. It will probably be a collectorrsquos itemyou donrsquot open it. But having tasted it, that will be a really big ldquo!www.adelphidistilleryGlenkinchie -year-oldABV: %Price: poundIrsquoll never forget it.It was a pub in Dundee ndash I canrsquot remember the name but I do remember the location the Queenrsquos Hotel at the bottom of the Perth Road ndash and it was , I think.And I didnrsquot like whisky, until that amazing night when I tried Glenkinchie.My friend had bet me he could find me one that would change my mind. When he handed the Glenkinchie to me he said: ldquoLook for the ice cream.And when I drank it, it was there, coating my mouth and at the back of my tongue hellip and I was hooked!Nowadays, Irsquod say therersquos far more to this dram than hints of vanilla and a lemon cheesecake creaminess. In fact, I think that for a Lowland malt ndash itrsquos distilled just outside Edinburgh ndash it has a wonderful richness and depth, and it really stands scrutiny against the biggest guns of Speyside, and some of the great Highland malts.Add to that a lovely natural, almost herbal note and you have a dram that really is one to remember.www.maltsArran The Bothy Quarter Cask Batch ABV: .%Price: pound.They say the Isle of Arran is Scotland in Miniature. But, believe me, therersquos nothing miniatureabout this fantastic dram from a lovely distillery in the north of the island.It packs as impressive a punch as any expresssion Irsquove tried over the years.As you can guess from the name, this is the fourth release of the Quarter Cask. Each one so far has been an absolute winner, and this is no dferent.The idea is simple: take the usual Arran whisky and, for the last  months of its maturation, move it into smaller casks ndash yes, you guessed it, a quarter the size of the original and made of American Oak.This allows far greater contact between whisky and wood, resulting in a faster, more intense maturation.The result is an absolutetreat ndash rich and powerful with tonsof vanilla sweetness and peppery spice. Itrsquos fruity and fresh, but at the same time really luxurious.This is a real star in a brilliant range. The distillery is well worth a visit too ndash the scones are amazing!www.arranwhiskyKilchoman SanaigABV: %Price: poundSpeed bonnie boat like a bird on the wing, over the sea to Skye. We all know the song about Bonnie Prince Charlie but, seriously,yoursquore looking for a Young Pretender, yoursquod be far better jumping on the ferry to Islay.Kilchoman is the newest of the distilleries on this little patch of land thatrsquos jam-packed with wonderful whisky, but itrsquos already giving its globally recognised neighbours a run for their money.Following on from the Machir Bay, Kilchoman ups its game a little with the Sanaig.Itrsquos described as a peaty malt, but for me itrsquos got that beautul aroma of Arbroath Smokies ndash sharp wood-ember smokiness mixed with a wonderful creaminess thatrsquos simply irresistible.Add to that light fruit, dark chocolate and raisins, along with red-berry richness, and you could be on a picnic on a beach with your pals, chatting and laughing until the last of the embers of the fire die down.A real treat ndash and brilliant value.kilchomandistilleryBenromach -year-oldABV: %Price: pound.Sometimes whisky isnrsquot about posh tasting notes and fancy descriptions of complex aromas and flavours. Sometimes itrsquos about something thatrsquos far more simple.Sometimes, when you smell it, it transports you somewhere  ndash to a memory or a favourite place.For me, this -year-old Benromach does just that. It takes me back to when I was young, six or seven, maybe, to a time when we lived in an old house, with a big open fire, and we used to sit there of an evening ndash it would have been about this time of year ndash roasting marshmallows.I can smell the fire ndash not a roaring one, but mellow embers with the odd little puff of smoke. I can taste the rich toffee-sweetness of the melting marshmallows.But, therersquos something  too ndash is that Jamaica ginger cake  Not homemade, but the sticky one out of the packet. Itrsquos luxurious, and it makes me smile.So,you have a whisky and the tasting notes donrsquot make any sense to you, donrsquot worry. More powerful forces may be at work ndash just open your mind and see what you can see.www.benromachCaol Ila -year-oldABV: %Price: poundThis is another one ndash another malt that holds a special place in my heart.When my two daughters were young, this was the one I remember sitting back with as the madness of Christmas began to subside at the end of the day. And itrsquos still the one Irsquoll go forI see it on a menu after dinner at a hotel.Caol Ilais a Muhammad Ali of a dram hellip it dances around, all lightness and fruit itrsquos fascinating and mesmerising.But at some point or other, you just know itrsquos going to knock you out with a wonderful smack of smoke.It starts off light and refined, with fresh herbal notes and hints of damp grass, but then the coastal smokiness really kicks in ndash not unlike hot-smoked salmon. Itrsquos full-bodied and has a long, warming finish.As you add water, a wonderful freshness ndash much like Ardbeg ndash takes over, making this a hugely satisfying dram.www.maltsOld Particular Cameronbridge -year-oldABV: .%Price: poundWe couldnrsquot let a list of brilliant whiskies go without including a single-grain. And what better place to find one than at legendary Glasgow-based independent bottler Douglas Laing The Cameronbridge isnrsquot exactly blessed with the beautul surroundings of Strathisla or Glengoyne, or the rugged backdrop of Dalwhinnie ndash it sits in Fersquos industrial heartland, just a stonersquos throw from Methil and Leven.It may not have had the most romantic of beginnings, but this Cameronbridge is a real ndash and rare ndash treat.In my mind, the defining characteristic of single-grain whiskies is cream, and this expression is awash with it.In fact, when you smell it, therersquos almost an aroma oftoffee sauce ndash salted caramel mixed with all that cream, but with a bit of honey thrown in for good measure.You could almost pour it on your sponge pudding.Therersquos cakiness too ndash in fact, this is more like a big, rich sharing dessert than a dram.Now, wherersquos my spoon  I want another helping .www.douglaslaingcomOld Pulteney -year-oldABV: %Price: poundIf anyone ever says that whisky isnrsquot a product of its surroundings, this is definitely a dram to make them change their mind.Itrsquos made in Wick, and its warehouses are exposed to the full force of the North Sea.This gives the whisky a wonderful coastal, salty personality ndash and once you get to know it, you can recognise it anywhere.But donrsquot think this dram is harsh in any way at all. The -year-old is aged entirely in bourbon casks, and this gives the finished product a wonderful richness and sweetness ndash and the distinctive vanilla that is always there when bourbon casks are used.Look for vanilla, tablet and almost burnt sugar on the nose, with a flavour balancing chocolate and toffee indulgence with citrusy fruit and that coastal tang.This level of quality is great value at pound, but be aware that Old Pulteneyis regularly on offer ndash I think itrsquos pound in Tesco right now, and at that price itrsquos a steal.www.oldpulteneyKilkerran -year-oldABV: %Price: poundBefore we start, letrsquos take a moment to thank Kilkerran ndash because the distillery where itrsquos made, Glengyle, effectively saved Campbeltownrsquos status as a whisky region.After many years of only having two distilleries, Springbank and Glen Scotia, it was deemed that Campbeltown could no longer be classed as a region.However, when Glengyle was resurrected ndash it was an old distillery that closed in the s but was brought back to le in  ndash the three operational distilleries could maintain their status.And just as well, as Campbeltown malts are unique ndash robust, oily and bursting with character ndash and this Kilkerran -year-old is certainly a classic of its kind.Itrsquos oaky and slightly peaty, but super-rich, sweet and velvety smooth at the same time. And, of course, therersquos the oiliness and saltiness yoursquod expect from a Campbeltown dram.This whisky was only launched in , but it surely deserves its place among the true greats of this amazing region.All hail Kilkerran ndash you are indeed a hero!kilkerran.scotMacallan -year-old Double CaskABV: %Price: poundThe Macallan has been looking a million dollars lately hellip literally. One of its bottles ndash a -year-old distilled in  ndash broke that mad, seven-figure barrier just a few weeks ago, but far more importantlythe distillery moved house hellip to possibly the most beautully perfect building I have ever seen.So, as the year draws to a close, I was pretty sure my impression of this superbrand couldnrsquot get any more positive hellip until I tasted the Double Cask.Much of my whisky journey has been a hunt for the dferent and the new, but when I come back to a dram like The Macallan and its perfect richness, I remember therersquos a reason why this is a worldwide favourite.The Double Cask uses whisky aged in barrels of both American and European ex-sherry oak to take the spirit to a whole new level.Therersquos the classic dried fruit. Itrsquos creamy and you can almost see the drops of honey. But therersquos the sweet sharpness of marmalade and almost the spiced luxury of a cinnamon pastry.A finish of vanilla and more sweet fruit and I have only one challenge on my mind as we end .Go on Macallan, I dare you ndash top that next year.www.themacallanArdbeg An OaABV: .%Price: poundTo me, Ardbeg is about only one thing ndash itrsquos what identies it the minute I stick my nose in the glass.Smoke ndash pure, perfect, wood-embers smoke.And the An Oa ndash launched last year as the first addition to Ardbegrsquos core range for more than a decade ndash doesnrsquot disappoint.Itrsquos there in spades, mixed with a wonderful cocktail of cakey sweetness and butterscotch richness. Therersquos a luxurious creaminess in the background too, just in case you didnrsquot get just how special this dram really is.Then,you add water therersquos another treat in store ndash something I donrsquot understand from such a peaty whisky, but which I always look for in an Ardbeg.The peaty oomph remains, but something  appears ndash the most wonderful freshness. Itrsquos like a summer breeze blowing through freshly washed linen just hung out to dry on a line by the sea.If you like peaty whisky, you really canrsquot go wrong with Ardbeg, but this was the first time Irsquod tried the An Oa.Time to rewrite my whisky wish-list, I think!www.ardbegGordon  MacPhail Discovery Bunnahabhain -year-oldABV: %Price: poundThere are Islay whiskies ndash the ones that take a barrowload of peat and stuff it down your throat ndash and there are Islay whiskies ndash the ones that tone things down, some a teeny bit, some a lot. For me, Bunnahabhain sits in the second camp hellip and itrsquos all the better for it.So when Gordon  MacPhail ndash one of the countryrsquos small band of legendary independent bottlers ndash gets hold of an already interesting dram, itrsquos time to take notice.This Discovery expression ndash part of a wider range from around the country ndash is rich and exciting, with dried fruit and sherry on the nose, and hints of spice, rich vanilla and orange. Itrsquos super- smooth, and as you taste it the initial spice morphs into more richness of dates and plums. At the finish, therersquos chocolate ndash maybe not milky bar, but definitely not bitter dark ndash and more fruits.The bottlerrsquos art is a critical part of the whisky firmament ndash they hunt out interesting casks and, when they find them they bottle them. Soyou see a bottlerrsquos version of one of our favourites, go for it ndash you will definitely be in for a memorable voyage of Discovery.gordonandmacphailNaked GrouseABV: %Price: poundAs I said in the introduction to this whole article,yoursquore after something truly memorable, you really donrsquot have to spend a fortune to get it hellipyou know where to look. And at under pound in some shops, the Naked Grouse is in my mind a must-have for any collection.Pour it for your whisky-loving friend ndash but donrsquot show them the bottle ndash and watch as they muse over the malty, toffee-sweet nose and rich fudgy, fruity flavour, topped off with a little spice, and tryto identy what high-end dram it belongs to.Soyoursquore looking for a superb, great-value dram, just remember one thing ndash sometimes less really is more.nakedgrouseTomatin -year-oldABV: %Price: poundAs you head up the A, by the time to reach Tomatin you know yoursquore in the Highlands. The bleak splendour of Drumochter and Dalwhinnie are miles behind the Cairngorms and Aviemore are a rapidly fading memory. Inverness isnrsquot far off, and from there itrsquos on to the wild lands of Ross and Caithness.Yoursquod expect a whisky here to have ruggedness its heart ndash to be as unforgiving as a northern winter. But no, not a bit of it. The climate round here is softer and more gentle than you might imagine ndash and the spirit thatrsquos born from this land reflects that.The Tomatin -year-old is smooth and silky, with a rich, fruity aroma coming from its traditional mix of ex-bourbon and ex-sherry casks. Itrsquos buttery at first, but there are also notes of marzipan. The flavours are powerful, but therersquos sweetness and richness, with oaky vanilla, ripe apples and pears. Hints of stem ginger and citrus add a tangy treat.Soyou ever thought the Highlands were bleak, think again. All you need to do is stop a while, look around you, and yoursquoll find a real gem hidden in the north.www.tomatinDouglas Laingrsquos Remarkable Regional MaltsABV: VariousPrice: From pound to poundI could choose one from this range, but really, therersquos no point. Quite simply,you try one you really should try them all, because theyrsquore as good a lesson in the dferent characteristics of Scotlandrsquos whisky regions as yoursquoll ever need. Theyrsquore a ready-made whisky collection.There are six names to look out for, and each blends together some of the best malts from its region to capture the unique character of each area.The fun, light Epicurean is the lowland offering, while rich,complex Speyside is represented by Scallywag.If you head into the Highlands, look out for Timorous Beastie, and slightly peated, slightly salty Rock Oyster is a island-inspired tidal wave.If yoursquore into a dram from Islay or Skye, why not try Big Beat , while the newest addition to the range,The Gauldrons, captures the unique, excellent power of Campbeltown.The range was launched with ldquobasic versions, but since then it has grown, and a host of special editions and extra expressions have turned these Regional Malts into a veritable reference library of whisky.So put on your reading glasses, pull up a chair and get studying. You will be tested at the end of the lesson.www.douglaslaingOld Pulteney HuddartABV: %Price: poundThis is a strange experience. Old Pulteney has been a favourite of mine for many, many years, but trying the Huddart ndash released just this year and named after the street in which the distillery sits ndash was like meeting the younger sister of my best pal that I didnrsquot know existed.I recognise her immediately, but at the same time shersquos so dferent from the friend I know and love.The Huddart is definitely an Old Pulteney ndash the saltiness and drtwood-on-a-beach coastal personality tell us that ndash but itrsquos been finished in casks which previously held peated whisky, and this gives it a wonderful far-off smokiness that adds a layer of real intensity to an already powerful dram.But therersquos a ton of richness too, with sweet vanilla balancing the intensity of smoke, and I loved the buttery, mouth-coating finish. This is definitely one to come back to on a cold, stormy night when I have some time on my hands, and the music player to myself. Van Morrison, I think.Huddart, itrsquos been a pleasure to make your acquaintance. I hope we run into each other again soon.www.oldpulteney.coTullibardine SovereignABV: %Price: poundAnd your starter for  ndash where do you think you would find the complete dram  The lush valleys of Speyside, perhaps  Or the rugged coast of Islay But whatI said just off theA on the way from Stirling to Perth Chances are yoursquoll have passed the Tullibardine distillery at one time or another. But did you know itrsquos one of the few in the country where every whisky-making process is done on-site Fermentation, distillation, maturation, and bottling ndash itrsquos all done here.This gives Tullibardine complete control over its whisky, and allows it to produce expressions like the Sovereign ndash a creamy, rich, delicious dram.On the nose, look for soft vanilla and cocoa butter, and when you taste it the richness builds with malt and hints of maple syrup, with a little extra helping of mixed peel and pears. The finish is all cream and vanilla with a touch of cinnamon-spice.For the whisky from the side of the A, itrsquos a definite A+ from me!www.tullibardine

title: pm-and-party-leaders-pay-tribute-to-paddy-ashdown
story: Sir Vince Cable and past Lib Dem leaders joined Theresa May, Jeremy Corbyn and others including Tony Blair in hailing the dedication and decency of the politician and former commando, who passed away on Saturday evening.The former party leader, who was credited with making the Lib Dems a signicant third force in politics during his tenure between  and , had announced he was suffering from bladder cancer in November.The party announced his passing, saying he would be remembered ldquoas someone who made an immeasurable contribution to furthering the cause of liberalism.Sir Vince Cable, the partyrsquos current leader, said it was ldquoa hugely sad day for the party and everyone  across politics ldquowho had immense affection and respect for Paddy.He hailed a man who ldquowas famous for his politics, but his talents extended well beyond that arena.Born in India and raised in Northern Ireland, he later served in the Royal Marines and Special Boat Service, including in Borneo and the Persian Gulf.He hit the headlines four years into his leadership of the Lib Dems when, in , he revealed he had had a five-month affair with his secretary, which led The Sun to nickname him ldquoPaddy Pantsdown.His marriage to we Jane survived the scandal.After stepping down as leader, Ashdown, who was MP for Yeovil from  to , was first knighted and then made a peer as Lord Ashdown of Norton-sub-Hamdon when he quit the Commons.He became High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina in May  and, more recently, went on to play a role in the Remain campaign during the  referendum, appearing alongside then-PM David Cameron and Lord Kinnock, the former Labour leader.After revealing his cancer diagnosis, he tweeted that it ldquodoes not merit a fuss, adding: ldquoMany go through this. The NHS guys in Yeovil Hosp. are BRILLIANT.ldquoI have the best of people and the best of friends to fight this with, which makes me, as so often in my le, very lucky.Sir Nick Clegg, who would as leader take the Liberal Democrats into government in , said Lord Ashdown had been ldquothe reason I entered politics and became ldquoa lelong mentor, friend and guide.He added: ldquoHe was a soldier, a diplomat, a writer, a leader, a campaigner, a servant of his constituents, and an international statesman.ldquoBut the thing I admired most in him is that rarest of gts ndash a politician without an ounce of cynicism.Tributes also came in from his former political opponents, with Sir John Major saying he was ldquoa man of duty, passion, and devotion to the country he loved ndash right up to the very end.Former Labour prime minister Tony Blair said he admired the former Lib Dem leader ldquoas a man and as a political visionary and leader, saying he had been ldquoexcellent company, always fun to be around.And Mr Blairrsquos successor Gordon Brown described Lord Ashdown as ldquoone of the towering political figures of our generation who spoke always as a strong European, a committed internationalist and a dedicated constitutional reformer.Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, hailed Lord Ashdownrsquos work in Bosnia, saying: ldquoPaddy Ashdown was an advocate for those others forgot, full of courage, integrity and immensely gted.ldquoHe served the people of the Balkans with passion and inspiration, an agent of reconciliation.Current Prime Minister Theresa May said Lord Ashdown had ldquoserved his country with distinction, adding: ldquoHe dedicated his le to public service and he will be sorely missed.Former Tory international development secretary Andrew Mitchell, who worked with him during the coalition years, said Lord Ashdown had been ldquoa wonderful man and a hugely effective politician who had been admired by Margaret Thatcher.Mr Mitchell told the Press Association: ldquoHe was an extraordinary character. Mrs Thatcher had immense respect for him and although he was a political opponent, held his views in the highest regard.

title: the-open-drives-120m-boost-for-scottish-economy
story: The th Open attracted a record , fans in July to watch the tournament won by Francesco Molinari, who became the first Italian to lt the Claret Jug.The Open has been played in Scotland more often than any other country, with Carnoustie hosting the event for the first time since , surpassing the , attendance record set in .An independent study found the economic impact of the tournament was a boost of pound million, in addition to pound million in destination marketing activity from The Open being broadcast on television to more than  million households in  countries.Welcoming the research by Sheffield Hallam Universityrsquos Sport Industry Research Centre, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: ldquoThe Open Championship is synonymous with Scotland as the home of golf, and this yearrsquos Open at Carnoustie once again showcased Scotland internationally as the perfect stage for major events.ldquoThe figures released today also demonstrate the economic benefits of hosting major events and Irsquom pleased the th Open generated signicant income for both the local Angus area and for the wider Scottish economy.ldquoWe look forward to bringing The Open back to Scotland in  when it s to St Andrews, and of course we will welcome the world to Gleneagles next September for the Solheim Cup.The study ndash which was commissioned by golfrsquos governing body the RA, VisitScotland and Angus Council ndash also concluded the Angus area alone received a pound million injection of new money from The Open.Almost half of the spectators who attendedtravelled from outside Scotland, while the majority of Scottish fanscame from outside Angus.Sixty-two per cent of non-Angus residents indicated they wouldto the region for a break within  months.David Fairweather, leader of Angus Council, said: ldquoWe were delighted to welcome The Open back, along with a record , fans. We all enjoyed a fantastic event that attracted global interest and attention, as well as immediate and long-lasting economic benefits to local and regional communities and business.ldquopound million of new money into the local economy is great news for Angus, its people, hotels, BBs, shops and restaurants.ldquoThe th Open at Carnoustie was outstanding and my message to those who joined us and to The RA is straightforward ndash Haste Ye Back.Martin Slumbers, RA chief executive, added: ldquoThe Open has a proven track record of generating substantial economic benefit for the host country in which it is staged thanks to the tens of thousands of spectators who attend each year.ldquoTheof The Open to Carnoustie has been a great success. We enjoyed a memorable week in which we welcomed a record number of fans to one of golfrsquos great championship venues to witness Francesco Molinari create history by becoming the first Italian to lt the iconic Claret Jug.

title: peace-walk-marks-30-years-on-from-the-lockerbie-bombing
story: Residents of the Dumfries and Galloway town and those who helped in the aftermath of the tragedy were among the -strong group taking part in the poignant event on Saturday.Religious leaders and representatives from Allanton World Peace Sanctuary also joined the gathering.The walkers scaled Burnswark, a flat-topped hill to the south of Lockerbie, which overlooks the area affected by the  tragedy.They carried with them  flags to represent the  nationalities of the victims of the air disaster.Krystal Anderson met the group at the summit after riding her white horse, named Rebel, from Tundergarth, as she carried the Lockerbie Standard.Ms Anderson is from one of the many local families that helped in the aftermath of the bombing.She said: ldquoSo many people were affected by the bombing, but the community really showed how strong it is, and everybody rallied round. Ever since then people from this area have been working for peace.ldquoI see the ride as being a way to help spread that message of peace.The hill walk was one of three linked Journey Towards Peace events that focus on hope, kindness and the need to end conflict.Jan Hogarth, an environmental artist working on the events, said: ldquoIn the decades since the bombing the people of this area have shown people kindness and compassion.ldquoThese events build on that positive process, bringing together people of all generations and of many backgrounds and beliefs with the common goal of spreading a message of peace and hope on earth.Susan Neal was another of the eventrsquos organisers.The -year-old of Lockerbie was in the town on the night of the atrocity, but said locals were ldquodone with their grieving.She said: ldquoThe walk had a sense of achievement, looking over the landscape, a beautul landscape.ldquoIt was very poignant, very interesting to talk to people on the walk and about why they chose to come.ldquoIt was moving, but wersquore moving on. We wanted to send a positive message about how we feel about the future.Jessica Wheeler, of May Peace Prevail on Earth International, also helped with the organisation.She said: ldquoThe land is very healing, being outside in that environment.ldquoI spoke to the farmer who was there, who found the first evidence of what happened.ldquoOccasionally, he can still smell it in the air, he still has some sense of it.

title: no-deal-brexit-default-position-if-no-alternative-deal-works-says-leadsom
story: The Brexiteer Commons Leader warned politicians lining up to block efforts to take the UK out of the EU in March without an alternative no-deal was the ldquolegal default position.Her comments in an interview with the Sundaycame after she spoke in support of a ldquomanaged no-deal as a possible alternative to the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement should it fail to pass the Commons in Januaryrsquos planned vote.In a sign of the widening splits in Tory thinking over no-deal, former chancellor George Osborne earlier warned that a no-deal Brexit could see the party stuck in opposition unless it abandoned the ldquoreckless decision of hard Brexiteers.Three Tory MPs ndash Nick Boles, Anna Soubry and Sarah Wollaston ndash have warned they would resign the whipa no-deal Brexit ever became official Government policy, and Justice Secretary David Gauke has suggested he would quit the Government.Mrs Leadsom, who publicly supports Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal, told the Sunday : ldquoParliament can always of course express a view, but in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit, Parliament does need to vote for a deal.She added: ldquoThe legal default position is thatthere isnrsquot a deal then the UK leaves the EU in March  without a deal.Writing in the same paper, Mr Boles spoke of how he left a hospital bed to vote for the triggering of Article .He said: ldquoI refuse to be bullied into accepting that crashing out of the EU with no deal would be an acceptable course for any British government to pursue.ldquoNor am I willing to swallow pie in the sky about how no-deal Brexit might be lsquomanagedrsquo or lsquomitigatedlsquo, especially when it is peddled by people who spent most or all of the last two-and-a-half years in Cabinet failing to make any preparations for this eventuality.Theresa Mayrsquos Withdrawal Agreement is due to be voted on by MPs in January. But few expect it to be approved by a heavily ided Commons, and Tory MPs including Cabinet ministers appear to have begun to polarise between those who might support a no-deal Brexit and those who would actively battle against it.However, Lib Dem MP Layla Moran, who supports the Best for Britain group backing a second referendum, insisted that MPs do have the power to stop a no-deal Brexit.She said: ldquoIs this really where the Brexiters have ended up  The merchants of lsquotake back controlrsquo have pivoted to lsquoyou canrsquot stop us from crashing the carrsquo.ldquoThis is a barking dog that will never bite. The reality is that Parliament can, and will, stop a no-deal Brexit. No politician worth their salt would allow such chaos and unnecessary harm.Earlier, Mr Osborne had launched a scathing attack on the Tories, warning that the party will not remain in power ldquounless it engages more with modern Britain and changes direction on Brexit.The politician-turned editor of the Evening Standard, who has been a vocal critic of Theresa May ndash who sacked him from the Cabinet in  ndash also attacked the Prime Ministerrsquos handling of negotiations.He accused her of following a ldquoBrexit means Brexit ideology because she backed Remain at the  referendum, ldquoalbeit sotto voce, and therefore ldquohad to prove her Brexit credentials.He told BBC Radio rsquos Today: ldquoThat was essentially a massive mistake by the Conservative administration, which it was punished for at the general election because the Conservative Party decided to embrace the Brexit result in such a way as to essentially dismiss the views of those who voted Remain, treat them as saboteurs or traitors, and run against urban Britain.Mr Osborne, who said he had warned then-PM David Cameron against holding the referendum in the first place, also attacked the ldquoreckless decision of hard Brexiteers to pursue a no-deal Brexit, saying: ldquoI donrsquot think the country voted to mobilise the Army, stockpile medicine, hoard food and go around the world buying every fridge available.ldquoThat is not what was offered and that is now what is happening.

title: samantha-markle-urges-meghan-to-end-the-rift-with-their-father
story: The Sunday Mirror reported Samantha, a paternal half-sister of Meghan, wrote to the royal saying it was ldquotime she reunited with father Thomas.According to Mr Markle, the relationship appears to have broken down and the father and daughter have not spoken for more than six months.The -year-oldwas caught up in controversy days before the wedding of Harry and Meghan after he allegedly staged paparazzi photographs of himself.In a picture of the card published by the Sunday Mirror, Samantha Markle wrote: ldquoHolidays are a time for family and are sentimental.ldquoDad has been trying to contact you and is very hurt because you are avoiding him.ldquoLe is short and you know Dad is wonderful. Please give him joy in his last years by showing you love him. The time is now.WORLD EXCLUSIVE: Meghan Markles father Thomas is hopeful hersquoll meet his grandchild and wants The Queen to help heal the rt between him and his daughter.https:t.co HUycqlyumdash Good Morning BritainDecember , Speaking from San Diego during an interview with Good Morning Britain earlier this week, Mr Markle made a public appeal to his daughter to get in touch.He said: ldquoIrsquom hopeful that soon something will be resolved and wersquoll be talking. This canrsquot continue forever.ldquoPeople are saying I should be quiet about this and not speak,I donrsquot speak, they will speak to me. That hasnrsquot happened. I donrsquot plan to be silent for the rest of my le.ldquoI love my daughter very much and she has to know that. I would really appreciateshe would just call me, reach out to me somehow, send me a text, just say yoursquore there and yoursquore hearing me.

title: how-the-royals-celebrate-christmas
story: But the American former actress is in the rare position of already having spent December  with the Windsors.She became the first non-married partner invited to Christmas lunch at Sandringham with the Queen in .Now an HRH and a duchess, the ex-Suits star is seven months into her royal le, and due to give birth to a royal baby in the spring.The traditions followed by the royal family at Christmas are a little dferent from many households in the UK.While most people across the country open their presents on Christmas Day, the royal family still keep to the German practice of opening their gts onChristmas Eve.Known as Heiligabend Bescherung , the tradition was popularised by Queen Victoria and Prince Albert.The Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh and other royals usually congregate in the White Drawing Room at Sandringham House the day before Christmas to put the finishing touches to a fttree cut from the estate.Presents are placed on a white linen-covered trestle table, with cards marking exactly where the piles of gts should be put.The Queen likes practical presents, but not overly extravagant ones, and the royals also reportedly like to exchange joke or non-costly quirky gts.Kate revealed that she was left stumped over what to buy the monarch for Christmas during her first stay at Sandringham.ldquoI thought back to what would I give my own grandparents. And I thought lsquoIrsquoll make her something.rsquo Which could have gone horribly wrong, the duchess said.ldquoBut I decided to make my grannyrsquos recipe of chutney. I was slightly worried about it, but I noticed the next day that it was on the table.Diana, Princess of Wales, once fell foul of the royal rules on present-giving, apparently buying cashmere sweaters as her first festive royal presents, and getting joke gts such as a loo-roll holder in .At pm, guests enjoy tea, scones, sandwiches and cakes from sideboards in the Saloon.Afterwards, they dress for dinner, with the men in black tie and the women in evening gowns, with the table set with the finest china.Sarah, Duchess of York, once described the royal Christmas asldquoexhausting, having changed outfits seven times in  hours.Sometime afterpm, on a signal from the Queen, the dorgis are led out and the ladies adjourn, leaving the Duke of Edinburgh to serve port or brandy to the men.On Christmas Day, the royals awake to find stockings filled with small gts and fruit at the foot of their beds.Their walk to the morning service at the Church of St Mary Magdalene on the royal estate is a traditional event where they greet well-wishers.Back at the house, lunch is prepared by their staff and served at pm, and the royals indulge in a giant turkey, reared at Sandringham.They then settle down to watch the Queenrsquos Christmas Speech.The Queen sometimes quietly leaves the room and lets her family watch the national address by themselves, as she views it alone to see how it comes across.Boxing Day, when the royals enjoy a breakfast buffet of kedgeree, bacon and eggs, often involves outdoor pursuits such as shooting, riding and walking.

title: how-to-ensure-gadget-gifts-are-safe-for-children-this-christmas
story: Smartphones, gaming consoles and smart speakers may well be under the tree this year, but what can parents do to keep the kids safe Ghislaine Bombusa, head of digital for Internet Matters, a non-profit set up by the countryrsquos leading internet service providers to improve childrenrsquos safety online, shares tips for parents to ensure their children can enjoy their new gadgets safely.Smartphones and tabletsldquoIf yoursquore going to give any device generally speaking, try to set it up before you wrap it up, Ms Bombusa warned.Where smartphones are concerned, make use of app store settings so that young people can only download apps suitable for them.Both iOS and Android offer a range of restrictions, which can lock down purchases from the app store and prevent explicit content.Children are likely to use YouTube, which can play host to some content more appropriate for adults. Enabling the websitersquos restricted mode helps to prevent children from accessing these videos.ldquoThe other thing you can possibly do is download some of the apps that you want them to use, so theyrsquore ready to go on the phone as you hand it to them, Ms Bombusa suggested.It is also advised to go through the device and switch off location services, as older children may be unintentionally sharing their location on social media apps.Gaming consolesGaming consoles feature parental controls, which allow parents to limit what children can do on devices such as the PlayStation  and Xbox One.Screen time settings allow grown-ups to decide specic times a child is allowed to play their console and how long for.Similar to smartphones, parents can also set spending limits to stop or restrict how much children buy in the game stores.LaptopsIf a child is getting a laptop this Christmas, itrsquos advised to set up a child account while an adult remains administrator, meaning parents have control over what they can download and access.Internet service providers offer broadband protection directly from the router, meaning inappropriate content and malware-infected websites are automatically filtered out as an added safety net, not just for laptops but all devices.Smart speakersSmart speakers such as the Amazon Echo and Google Home include protections against the ability to buy products, and that can help block any inappropriate content, such as music with expletives.Many of these controls can be found within the accompanying app used to set up the device or from the device makerrsquos website.Most importantly, Internet Matters recommends having regular conversations with children about how they use their gadgets.

title: us-government-unlikely-to-get-fully-back-to-business-for-days
story: From coast to coast, the first day of the shutdown played out in uneven ways.The Statue of Liberty was still open for tours, thanks to money from New York state, and the US Post Office was still delivering mail, as an independent agency.Yet the disruption has affected many government operations and the routines of , federal employees.Roughly , workers were deemed essential and were expected to work unpaid.The crisis of illegal activity at our Southern Border is real and will not stop until we build a great Steel Barrier or Wall. Let work begin!mdash Donald J. TrumpDecember , I will not be going to Florida because of the Shutdown ndash Staying in the White House! #MAGAmdash Donald J. TrumpDecember , An additional , were to given a leave of absence, meaning they will stay home without pay.The Senate had already passed legislation ensuring that workers will receive back pay, and the House was likely to follow suit.No one knew how long the closures would last.Unlike other shutdowns, this one seemed to lack urgency, coming during the long holiday weekend after Mr Trump had already declared Monday, Christmas Eve, a federal holiday.Rather than work around the clock to try to end the shutdown, as they had done in the past, the leaders of the House and the Senate effectively closed up shop.But they did not rule out actiona deal were struck.ldquoListen, anything can happen, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told reporters after he closed the Senatersquos rare Saturday session hours after it opened.But after ushering Vice President Mike Pence through the Capitol for another round of negotiations, the Republican chairman of the Appropriations Committee, Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama, said a quick end to the shutdown was ldquonot probable.At the White House, Mr Trump hosted a lunch on Saturday with conservative politicians, including House Freedom Caucus chiefs Mark Meadows of North Carolina and Jim Jordan of Ohio, and several senators.Absent from the guest list were Republican leaders or any Democrats, who would be needed for a deal.ldquoI am in the White House, working hard, tweeted the president, who cancelled his Florida holiday getaway to his club Mar-a-Lago due to the shutdown.OUR GREAT COUNTRY MUST HAVE BORDER SECURITY! pic ZGcYygMfamdash Donald J. TrumpDecember , First lady Melania Trump was flying back to Washington to be with her husband.Mr Trumprsquos re-election campaign sent out a fundraising email late on Saturday launching what he called ldquothe most important membership program ever ndash the OFFICIAL BUILD THE WALL MEMBERSHIP.The president urged donors to sign up.With Democrats set to take control of the House on January , and Speaker Paul Ryan on his way out, the shutdown was providing a last gasp of the conservative majority before the new Congress.Mr Trump savoured the prospect of a shutdown over the wall for months.Last week he said he would be ldquoproud to close down the government.He had campaigned on the promise of building the wall, and he also promised Mexico would pay for it. Mexico has refused to do so.In recent days, though, Mr Trump tried to sht blame to Democrats for not acceding to his demand. He has given mixed messages on whether he would sign any bill into law.After the luncheon at the White House, Senator Lindsey Graham said, ldquoItrsquos clear to me he believes the additional funding is necessary.Senators approved a bipartisan deal earlier in the week to keep the government open into February and provide . billion dollarsfor border security projects, but not the wall.A test vote in the Senate on Friday showed that Republicans lacked the  votes needed to advance the House plan.

title: tory-party-sparks-social-media-storm-after-posting-poll-about-festive-food-as-thousands-face-christmas-on-the-breadline
story: The poll, published from the official Conservative Party Twitter account on Friday, said: "Right, time now for an all-important Christmas poll: which is better " Giving followers the options of choosing either mince pies or pigs in blankets as answers.Over , Twitter users have responded to the poll with the majority highlighting the Conservative Governments failings to address the rising poverty crisis affecting the UK.Many Twitter users responded to the poll calling it "distasteful" and "disgraceful" with many commenting on how "out of touch" the Tory Party is with society.In response to the poll, James Lazarus posted: "Distasteful considering the mess UK is in right now because of your party. Millions will have a rotten Christmas because of the Tory austerity policy and the rubbish Tory Brexit you want to inflict on the country."Julie Peel created her own pollin response with the choices of eating or heating.Ben Williams posted: "The #irony of this Tweet when @Conservatives policies have reduced families to starvation. Food bank use has gone through the roof since . Shameful."Dale Ricketts posted: "Scrolled as far down as I can in this thread without smashing my head against a brick wall... not a single positive response was seen. How are you Tories still so out of touch with reality "Mark Willett also responded to the poll commenting onthe Tories detachment from public opinion: "A tweet from people who really donrsquot have ANY idea how far detached they are from public opinion and Irsquod say the sameany other party tweeted this insignicant nonsense."But in amongst the negative comments and robust replies, a few Twitter users showed support for the Conservative Government.Nora Rose responded to the negativity by tweeting: "Dont just blame the Conservatives blame the whole of Parliament. By arguing like Ally cats over the way we leave, trading insults, and pushing for a General Electiontime for nought !"Study findings released today revealed that homelessness has reached a record-high with more than , families and iniduals experiencing destitution in an increase caused by a doubling of those sleeping rough or in tents, cars and public transport.The scale of homelessness was % higher last year compared to , with an increase seen every year in between, according to the research published by charity Crisis.Over five years in Great Britain, these types of precarious living are believed to have increased by around %.

title: council has its say on a96 route plan
story: The thorny issue of the preferred route between Inverurie and Huntly as part of the Scottish Government#s planned dualling of the A was debated by councillors on Thursday.In its agreed statement to Transport Scotland, Aberdeenshire Council’s Infrastucture Services Committeeconfirmed its strategic preference for route options to the north-east of Inverurie having seen its preferred Option Q route discarded by the roads authority.The council will now advise Transport Scotland that it considers that the “greatest strategic benefits” for the area can be achieved by pursuing route options that run to north-east of Inverurie.That option, it states, will relieve traffic pressure in Inverurie by enabling businesses and households in the Oldmeldrum, Rothienorman and Uryside catchment areas to access the trunk road network without having to pass through the town centre.A north-east route would also facilitate the future development of Inverurie and its town centre, provide opportunities to aid economic development associated with enhanced access to the strategic road network for communities and businesses to the north and north-east of the current A and A corridors and help development opportunities in the Oldmeldrum area, and further to the north.It has also reiterated the importance of further proactive, meaningful and early engagement with officers, councillor, communities and stakeholders.The ISC also considered comment from the council’s area committees prior to making its decision.Garioch Area Committee noted a preference for the route to be as close as possible to the current alignment of the A as this was felt to be the least disruptive option.It also noted concerns regarding the option in relation to splitting the communities of title: driving help and advice for youngsters
story: Twelve youngsters recently took part in a Rrrrallye Youth Drive event to learn more about how to be safe while behind the wheel.The group received support and advice from Dave Watson and Jim Howard, driving instructors from Roadwise Driver Training, at the Grampian Transport Museum on Sunday, December .Dave and Jim have been instructing youngsters for the Rrrrallye Youth Drive since  and have given  youngsters tuition on safe and considerate driving skills focusing on Road Hazard Awareness.The Rrrrallye Team said: “We really appreciate the support and encouragement they have given us.“We are always amazed at how much information and skills the youngsters manage to pick up in the short period of time they are there.”The Rrrrallye Youth Drive was made possible by Alan Sibbald who managed to secure funding from Garioch and North Marr Community Safety Group.The youngsters who took part in the Rrrrallye Youth Drive this year were Keigan Mathers, Sophie Orr, Warren Clark, Jane Rennie, Dean Gray, Jon Dalmon, Cameron Topp, Greg Smith, Ross Coutts, Ben Middleton, Leo Gibson and Libby Sullivan.The Rrrrallye Team organise a special Rrrrallye day every year in memory of Stuart Harper who sadly died following a car collision in May  just  days before his th birthday.Funds raised from the annual event is used to purchase vouchers for young drivers aged between  and , allowing them to get money off a Pass Plus or Advanced Driving Course.The courses will give the drivers more knowledge on how to handle their cars while driving on any road conditions.The next Rrrrallye Car Show and family fun day will be held on Sunday, June , , what would have been Stuart’s birthday.The event will be held at the Keith Community Sports and Leisure Centre.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
